cluster_classes.class_description: Highly corrosive acids requiring specific materials for safe handling and storage.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: require specific materials to safely manage these corrosive substances.

members.entity_description: A strong acid used in various industrial processes, requiring specific materials for safe handling.
A highly corrosive acid used in industrial applications, requiring special materials for safe handling and storage.

cluster_classes.class_description: Corrosion mechanisms affecting external surfaces, including underground, submerged, and beneath insulation systems.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Corrosion on external surfaces and beneath insulation.

members.entity_description: Corrosion occurring on the outer surfaces of underground or submerged metallic piping systems.
Corrosion that occurs beneath insulation materials, often exacerbated by trapped moisture.

cluster_classes.class_description: Corrosion mechanisms occurring at elevated temperatures, including oxidation and sulfidation.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Corrosion at high temperatures, affecting material integrity.

members.entity_description: A chemical reaction that stainless steels resist due to their alloy content.
A chemical reaction that stainless steels resist due to their alloy content.
Corrosion occurring at elevated temperatures, affecting material integrity.

cluster_classes.class_description: Corrosion processes, including oxidation and sulfidation, that are resisted by stainless steels and other high-temperature alloys.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Stainless steels resist various forms of corrosion.

members.entity_description: A broad process that stainless steels resist due to their alloy content, encompassing various forms like oxidation and sulfidation.
A chemical reaction that stainless steels resist due to their alloy content.
A chemical reaction that stainless steels resist due to their alloy content.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals caused by hydrogen, including SOHIC and HIC.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Cracking in hydrogen-exposed steel, often near welds.

members.entity_description: A type of cracking in steel caused by the presence of hydrogen and stress, often near welds, characterized by cracks aligned nearly perpendicular to stress.
Stepwise internal cracks in metal connecting hydrogen blisters, occurring without external stress.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals due to sulfide and acid environments, including sulfide stress cracking and polythionic acid stress corrosion cracking.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Cracking in sulfide and acid environments.

members.entity_description: A form of hydrogen embrittlement that occurs in metals exposed to sulfide environments.
A type of corrosion that affects austenitic stainless steels and other austenitic alloys during shutdowns.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in metals due to environmental factors, including wet H2S environments and carbon steel weldments.

members.entity_description: Cracking of pressure vessels in environments containing wet hydrogen sulfide.

members.entity_name: environmental cracking of carbon steel weldments
members.entity_description: Cracking that occurs in carbon steel weldments due to environmental factors in corrosive environments.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cracking mechanisms in materials due to stress and corrosive environments, including stress corrosion cracking and environment assisted cracking.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Cracking due to stress and corrosive environments.

members.entity_description: A failure mechanism where cracks form in a material due to the combined effects of tensile stress and a corrosive environment.
Cracking of materials facilitated by environmental conditions.

cluster_classes.class_description: Methods used to inspect materials for defects without causing damage, including radiographic, ultrasonic, visual, and magnetic particle testing.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Methods in the FOCUS chunk for detecting defects.

members.entity_description: A non-destructive testing method using X-rays or gamma rays to view the internal structure of a component.
An ultrasonic testing method using shear waves to detect flaws in materials.
A non-destructive testing method using high-frequency sound waves to detect internal flaws.
A non-destructive testing method involving the visual examination of a component.
A non-destructive testing method using fluorescent particles to detect surface and near-surface defects.

cluster_classes.class_description: Mechanisms causing material degradation, including mechanical, metallurgical, and thickness loss processes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The mechanisms are divided into sections: a) Mechanical and Metallurgical Failure, b) Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness.

cluster_classes.class_description: The Heat Affected Zone (HAZ) is the area of base metal near a weld that has not melted but has undergone changes in microstructure and mechanical properties due to welding heat.

members.entity_description: The portion of the base metal adjacent to a weld with altered microstructure and properties due to welding heat.

cluster_classes.class_description: Failure mechanisms related to mechanical and metallurgical processes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The mechanisms are divided into sections: a) Mechanical and Metallurgical Failure, b) Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness.

members.entity_description: Failure mechanisms related to mechanical and metallurgical processes in various industries.

cluster_classes.class_description: Mechanisms involving uniform or localized loss of material thickness.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The mechanisms are divided into sections: a) Mechanical and Metallurgical Failure, b) Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness.

members.entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness
members.entity_description: A damage mechanism involving the reduction of material thickness, either uniformly or in specific areas.

args.new_description: Corrosion mechanisms including general, oxidation, and sulfidation processes, particularly those resisted by stainless steels and high-temperature alloys.
args.justification: Significant entity overlap (oxidation, sulfidation) and highly similar descriptions indicate these classes represent the same underlying corrosion mechanisms at high temperature and general conditions.
Assigning unified Class_Group 'Corrosion Mechanisms' to merged corrosion mechanism class for schema consistency.
Class describes external corrosion mechanisms and should be grouped with other corrosion mechanism classes.
Class correctly describes corrosive acids as materials; Class_Group is appropriate and confirmed.
Class correctly describes a welded component feature; Class_Group is appropriate and confirmed.
Class correctly describes inspection/testing methods; Class_Group is appropriate and confirmed.
Class describes hydrogen-induced cracking mechanisms and fits with other cracking mechanism classes.
Class describes sulfide and acid stress cracking, which is a material cracking mechanism.
Class describes environmental cracking, which is a material cracking mechanism.
Class describes general stress corrosion cracking, which is a material cracking mechanism.
Class is a high-level grouping for material damage mechanisms and should be assigned to the corresponding Class_Group.
Class describes mechanical and metallurgical failure mechanisms and should be grouped under Material Damage Mechanisms.
Class describes thickness loss mechanisms and should be grouped under Material Damage Mechanisms.
